header_summary:
Ava Chow announced the availability of Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc2 binaries for community engagement, with the source code accessible for review, marking a significant step towards the official release pending feedback on this candidate version. This release emphasizes the project's commitment to transparency and informed user participation, with preliminary notes detailing improvements available for exploration [here](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/v28.1rc2/doc/release-notes.md).

The discussions on operational code OP_CTV, as highlighted by stutxo and others, delve into its implications on transaction fee adjustments, particularly the challenges presented by the inability to use Replace-By-Fee (RBF) for dynamic fee rate adjustments. This discourse extends to strategies enabled by Bitcoin 28.0, such as Child Pays For Parent (CPFP), to mitigate fee market sensitivity, suggesting evolving transaction frameworks could offer solutions to these inherent limitations [source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/5565b149-48b7-4823-9363-89cfd70ecf09n@googlegroups.com).

Michael Cassano's discussion, based on an exchange between George Burke and John, underscores the importance of maintaining the current nomenclature within the Bitcoin network to honor Satoshi Nakamoto's legacy and minimize systemic changes. This conversation reflects on the foundational aspects of Bitcoin and the practical implications of terminology adjustments within the development community [source](https://gnusha.org/pi/bitcoindev/CAAg3Je02CszYvwF1kL3DofpnxXZvBZx7GAJaM2y1z6ePiG5Y2A@mail.gmail.com).

The exploration of MATT, particularly focusing on `OP_CAT` for creating vector commitments and the role of covenants in executing protocols, showcases the innovative approaches to verifying Merkle proofs and enabling dynamic state computations across multiple UTXOs. This discussion highlights the potential of MATT to transform the execution of protocols without the need for presigned transactions, inviting further exploration and collaborative development [source](https://merkle.fun).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 28.1 Release Candidate 2 Available
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.1rc2 binaries and source code are now available for download and review.
- Preliminary release notes for v28.1rc2 outline changes and improvements, emphasizing transparency.
- This release candidate marks an essential step towards the final v28.1 release, dependent on feedback and bug reports.

recent_posts.title: TRUC and P2A for CTV fee management
recent_posts.summary:
- OP_CTV's static fee problem challenges long-term vault dynamics due to fee market unpredictability.
- New Bitcoin v3 transactions introduce fee bumping via CPFP, offering solutions to OP_CTV's limitations.
- These innovations prompt further investigation on their broader impacts and efficiency in CTV script spends.

recent_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Redefinition of the Bitcoin Unit to the Base Denomination
recent_posts.summary:
- George outlines the benefits of not changing "bitcoin" terminology.
- He emphasizes honoring Satoshi Nakamoto's legacy via terminology.
- The approach simplifies rollout by gradually phasing in "sats."

recent_posts.title: A Fast, Scalable Protocol For Resolving Lightning Payments
recent_posts.summary:
- The revised paper version 1.1 outlines improvements in speed and scalability of the OPR protocol.
- It compares the OPR protocol's security with the Lightning protocol for small payments.
- Emphasizing protocol adherence is vital for security and preventing theft in transactions.

recent_posts.title: Timewarp attack 600 second grace period
recent_posts.summary:
- The discussion explores manipulating the `nTime` parameter to optimize blockchain mining efficiency.
- Risks of invalid blocks arise if `nTime` adjustments exceed 600 seconds, but remain minimal within limits.
- Proposals include regulating block timestamp rules to prevent invalid blocks while optimizing mining strategies.

recent_posts.title: Optimistic ZK verification using MATT
recent_posts.summary:
- `OP_CAT` in MATT facilitates vector commitments, crucial for Merkle proofs.
- Covenants in MATT enable protocol execution as arbitrary state machines across UTXOs.
- A compilation of MATT resources is available at [merkle.fun](https://merkle.fun) for deeper exploration.

active_posts.title: Trivial QC signatures with clean upgrade path
active_posts.summary:
- Quantum computing may break Bitcoin's encryption, but provides a warning period for security upgrades.
- Hash-based signatures like SPHINCS/SPHINCS+ are seen as the best post-quantum security options for Bitcoin.
- A taproot-based solution for post-QC security is proposed, with alternatives to address potential drawbacks.

active_posts.title: BIP Draft: "ChillDKG: Distributed Key Generation for FROST"
active_posts.summary:
- Jonas, Nick, and Tim are drafting a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal on FROST Threshold Signatures.
- Their proposal, available on GitHub, seeks community feedback for refinement and development.
- It highlights ongoing efforts to enhance cryptographic methods in the Bitcoin ecosystem.

active_posts.title: Proposal for Quantum-Resistant Cryptography in Bitcoin - BIP Submission
active_posts.summary:
- The BIP proposes introducing quantum-resistant cryptography to Bitcoin, featuring SPHINCS+ and Dilithium.
- It includes a soft fork for backward compatibility and smooth transition for Bitcoin's network enhancements.
- Agustín Cruz invites community review and feedback to refine the quantum-resistant feature integration.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal examines Bitcoin's flaws and suggests improvements for security and efficiency.
- It targets specific vulnerabilities like the timewarp exploit and proposes solutions to enhance stability.
- Community engagement is encouraged for addressing bugs, with debates on block size affecting scalability.

active_posts.title: PPLNS with job declaration
active_posts.summary:
- An SV2 extension is being developed to enhance mining pool payout transparency and fairness.
- The extension grants miners the ability to select transactions, influencing their fee structures.
- The project, still in development, welcomes reviews to refine the proposed system.

active_posts.title: CTV, APO, CAT activity on signet
active_posts.summary:
- BIPs 118, 119, and 347 brought new scripting capabilities to Bitcoin.
- APO usage in BIP 118 shows strategic transaction structuring, reducing reliance on output histories.
- BIP 347's OP_CAT sees extensive use, impacting Bitcoin's security and transaction functionality.

today_in_history_posts.title: BIP Proposal: Wallet Interface
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- This BIP aims to standardize a wallet interface for broader Bitcoin application development.
- It proposes exposing wallet functions to facilitate time lock and multi-sig web applications.
- Security concerns are emphasized due to the external accessibility of wallet functionalities.

today_in_history_posts.title: PoDLEs revisited
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Rusty Russell inquired about a heuristic's applicability post-Taproot.
- Taproot maintains privacy against certain methods of identifying channel funders.
- The discussed method aims to link UTXOs with node IDs, thwarting UTXO probes.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin scalability involves creating 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for 1 billion weekly users.
- High transaction costs on the main chain push towards semi-trusted, interconnected off-chain services.
- Solutions include smart contracts, Utreexo for UTXO optimization, and Layer 2 protocols like the Lightning Network.
